general: The Finance Act 2005 is a law passed by the UK government to change taxes and how the country's debt and revenue are managed. It includes measures to increase some taxes and reduce others, as well as changes to the way the government borrows money and spends it. The goal of the act is to make sure the country has enough money to provide public services and pay for important things like schools, hospitals, and the military.

series.short: "UK Tobacco Duty Rates: A Guide to New Taxes on Cigarettes, Cigars, and More"
series.text:
* The simplified version of this extract is that it sets out the rates of duty for different types of tobacco products in the UK, specifically cigarettes, cigars, hand-rolling tobacco, and other smoking tobacco and chewing tobacco.
* The rates of duty are based on the weight or quantity of the product, with different amounts applying to each type of product. For example, cigarettes are taxed at a rate of £102.39 per thousand, while cigars are taxed at a rate of £149.12 per kilogram.
* The legislation also specifies when the new rates of duty will come into effect, which is at 6 o'clock in the evening of 16th March 2005.

series.short: "New Duty Rates for Alcoholic Beverages Take Effect in the UK"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The rate of duty on beer has been increased from £12.59 to £12.92.
* Simplified point 2: The rates of duty on wine and made-wine have been adjusted based on their strength, with different rates applying depending on the alcohol content.
* Simplified point 3: The changes apply to wine and made-wine imported or produced in the UK, and take effect from midnight on March 20th, 2005.

series.short: "UK Hydrocarbon Oil Duty Rates Update"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text outlines changes to the rates of hydrocarbon oil duties in the UK, effective from September 1st, 2005.
* Simplified point 2: The updates include adjustments to the prices of various types of fuels, such as ultra-low sulfur petrol, sulphur-free petrol, light oil, and heavy oil.
* Simplified point 3: The new rates are as follows:
	+ Ultra-low sulfur petrol: £0.4832 per liter (up from £0.4710)
	+ Sulphur-free petrol: £0.4832 per liter (up from £0.4710)
	+ Light oil: £0.5766 per liter (up from £0.5620)
	+ Heavy oil: £0.5465 per liter (up from £0.5327)
	+ Biodiesel: £0.2832 per liter (up from £0.2710)
	+ Bioethanol: £0.2832 per liter (up from £0.2710)
	+ Road fuel gas: £0.1080 per kilogram (up from £0.0900)
* Simplified point 4: The changes aim to reflect the increase in the Retail Prices Index (RPI) since the last review in March 2005.

series.short: "Gaming Duty Rates Amended in Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* This extract of the Finance Act 2005 changes the rates of gaming duty for certain amounts of gross gaming yield.
* Prior to this change, the rate of gaming duty was 2.5% for the first £534,500 of gross gaming yield, 12.5% for the next £1,186,500, and 20% for any amount above that.
* After this change, the rates will be 2.5% for the first £534,500, 12.5% for the next £1,186,500, 20% for the next £1,186,500, and 30% for any amount above that.
* The change only applies to accounting periods beginning on or after April 1st, 2005.

series.short: "UK Government Updates Vehicle Excise Duty Rates for Greener Cars."
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government is making changes to the Vehicle Excise Duty (VED) rates for certain types of vehicles.
* Simplified point 2: The changes include adjusting the annual rates of duty for light passenger vehicles based on their CO2 emissions figures, and updating the rates for buses and haulage vehicles that meet certain environmental standards.
* Simplified point 3: The new rates will apply to licenses taken out on or after March 17th, 2005, and will affect vehicles registered on or after March 1st, 2001.
* Simplified point 4: The changes also include updates to the trailer supplement rates, and the removal of certain subsections related to the rounding of rates.

series.short: "UK Government Introduces Special Trust Tax Rate for 2005-06"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has introduced a new tax rate for the year 2005-06, which will be applied to certain types of income. This new rate is called the "special trust rate".
* Simplified point 2: The special trust rate will only apply to income that is earned by trusts, and not to other types of income.
* Simplified point 3: The special trust rate will be charged at 19% for the financial year 2005.
* Simplified point 4: The special trust rate will only apply to the first slice of trust income, meaning that any income earned beyond that amount will be subject to different tax rates.
* Simplified point 5: The special trust rate will not apply to income that is subject to a different type of tax, such as dividend tax or capital gains tax.

series.short: "Tax Law Changes: Expanding Exemptions for Childcare, Parking, Cycles, and Armed Forces Pensions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text describes changes to existing laws related to personal taxation, specifically regarding childcare vouchers, workplace parking, cycles, and armed forces pensions.
* Simplified point 2: The changes aim to expand the scope of existing exemptions for certain benefits, such as childcare vouchers, workplace parking, and cycles, and introduce new exemptions for outplacement services and armed forces pensions.
* Simplified point 3: The changes also include updates to existing provisions related to the calculation of exemptions for childcare vouchers and the treatment of previously loaned computers or cycles.
* Simplified point 4: The extension of outplacement services exemptions to part-time employees and the introduction of a new exemption for armed forces pensions are significant changes introduced by the legislation.
* Simplified point 5: The amendments made by the legislation have effect for the year 2005-06 and subsequent years of assessment, except for the amendment made by subsection (2), which has effect for the year 2005-06 only.

series.short: UK Research Institution Share Scheme Tax Relief
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This chapter of the UK legislation provides tax relief for employees who acquire shares in a spin-out company from a research institution, provided certain conditions are met.
* Simplified point 2: The relief is only available if the employee is involved in research related to the intellectual property being transferred, and the avoidance of tax is not the main purpose of the arrangements.
* Simplified point 3: The market value of the shares is calculated disregarding the effect of the intellectual property agreement and any transfer of intellectual property.
* Simplified point 4: If the shares are restricted securities, the employer and employee must be treated as making an election under section 431(1) of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003.
* Simplified point 5: The chapter also defines "intellectual property" and "transfer" for the purposes of the relief, and sets out supplementary provisions regarding the meaning of "research institution" and "involved in research".

series.short: "Finance Act 2005: Research Institution Spin-Out Companies & Employment Income"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 deals with the tax treatment of research institution spin-out companies.
* Simplified point 2: The section provides for an election to be made by the employee and the employer to treat certain shares or interests in shares as employment income, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 3: If the election is made, the taxable amount will be the market value of the shares minus any deductions allowed, and it will be treated as employment income for the tax year in which the chargeable event occurs.
* Simplified point 4: The section also provides for the modification of provisions in the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 and the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 in relation to shares or interests in shares that are restricted securities or convertible securities.
* Simplified point 5: The section gives the Treasury the power to make regulations to modify the provisions of the Act in relation to these types of shares or interests in shares.

series.short: "Changes to Capital Gains Tax Rules for Share Acquisitions in Research Institution Spin-Out Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 makes changes to the Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rules regarding the calculation of the gain on the disposal of certain types of shares. Specifically, it adds new sections 149AB and 149AC to the Taxation of Chargeable Gains Act 1992 (TCGA 1992).
* Simplified point 2: The new section 149AB sets out the rules for determining the consideration for the acquisition of shares in research institution spin-out companies. It states that the consideration must be equal to the aggregate of the actual amount or value given for the shares and any amount that constitutes earnings under Chapter 1 of Part 3 of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003 (ITEPA 2003).
* Simplified point 3: The new section 149AC provides that the amendments made by this section only apply to the individual making the acquisition and do not affect the calculation of the consideration received by the person from whom the shares are acquired.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by this section have effect in relation to any disposal (whether before or after the passing of this Act), except for the amendment made by paragraph (b) of subsection (2), which only has effect in relation to disposals on or after 6th April 2005.

series.short: "Tax Provisions for Trusts Benefiting Vulnerable Persons"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This chapter of the Finance Act 2005 deals with tax provisions related to income arising to trustees from property held on qualifying trusts for the benefit of a vulnerable person.
* Simplified point 2: The chapter covers various aspects, including claims for special tax treatment, definitions of "vulnerable person" and "qualifying trusts", and provisions related to income tax and capital gains tax.
* Simplified point 3: Trustees can make a claim for special tax treatment if they hold property on qualifying trusts for the benefit of a vulnerable person and a vulnerable person election is in effect for all or part of the tax year.
* Simplified point 4: The chapter provides detailed rules for determining which trusts are considered qualifying trusts and how to calculate the tax due on the income earned from these trusts.

series.short: "Special Tax Treatment for Vulnerable Individuals with Income from Qualifying Trusts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation provides special tax treatment for vulnerable individuals who receive income from qualifying trusts.
* Simplified point 2: The trustees of these trusts can claim special tax treatment for the income arising from the trusts, which reduces their liability to income tax.
* Simplified point 3: The amount of relief is calculated based on the income tax liability of the trustees and the vulnerable individual, and certain expenses incurred by the trustees can be deducted from their liability.
* Simplified point 4: Non-UK residents can still claim this special tax treatment, but their income tax liability is computed using the assumptions that they are resident and domiciled in the UK.
* Simplified point 5: If income is distributed to the vulnerable individual from the trusts, it is disregarded in calculating their income tax liability.
* Simplified point 6: Any relief given to the vulnerable individual by way of a reduction in their income tax liability is also disregarded in calculating their liability.

series.short: Vulnerable Individual Capital Gains Tax Relief: Special Rules for Trusts
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the legislation provides special capital gains tax treatment for vulnerable individuals who receive gains from trusts.
* Simplified point 2: The gains are subject to capital gains tax, but the tax rate is reduced based on the individual's residency status and the amount of gains attributable to the trust.
* Simplified point 3: Non-UK resident vulnerable individuals are eligible for a reduction in their capital gains tax liability, while UK resident vulnerable individuals are subject to different rules and rates.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation defines "qualifying trusts" and "settled property" and outlines how gains are attributed to the vulnerable individual.
* Simplified point 5: The section also includes provisions for determining the vulnerable individual's liability and the amount of relief available.

series.short: "Qualifying Trusts for Disabled Persons and Minors Outlined in Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract defines qualifying trusts for the purposes of the Finance Act 2005, specifically for disabled persons and relevant minors.
* Simplified point 2: Qualifying trusts must meet certain conditions, such as ensuring that the disabled person or relevant minor benefits from the trust, and that the trust does not allow for the application of income for the benefit of anyone else.
* Simplified point 3: The extract outlines the types of trusts that are considered qualifying trusts, including trusts for the benefit of disabled persons and relevant minors, and trusts established under the Will of a deceased parent or under the Criminal Injuries Compensation Scheme.
* Simplified point 4: The powers conferred on trustees by the Trustee Act 1925 and the Trustee Act (Northern Ireland) 1958 do not affect the qualification of trusts under this chapter.

series.short: "Election for Vulnerable Person Under Finance Act 2005: Trustee's Guide"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract describes the process of making an election for a "vulnerable person" under the Finance Act 2005. This allows trustees to make claims for tax relief on behalf of a beneficiary who is a vulnerable person, such as a disabled person or a minor who has lost a parent.
* Simplified point 2: To make a vulnerable person election, the trustees and the beneficiary must jointly submit a written notice to the Inland Revenue within 12 months of the end of the tax year in which the election is to take effect. The notice must include information about the trusts, the trustees, the vulnerable person, and their entitlement under the trusts.
* Simplified point 3: A vulnerable person election is irrevocable once it has been made, and it remains in effect until the beneficiary ceases to be a vulnerable person or the trusts are terminated. If the trustees become aware of an event that renders the election invalid, they must inform the Inland Revenue within 90 days.
* Simplified point 4: The extract defines a "disabled person" for the purposes of the chapter, and outlines the criteria for determining whether a person is a disabled person eligible for a vulnerable person election. It also explains how a person can be treated as a disabled person under certain circumstances.

series.short: "Vulnerable Persons' Elections: Inland Revenue Powers and Appeals"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The chapter outlines the power of the Inland Revenue to make inquiries regarding vulnerable persons' elections.
* Simplified point 2: If the Inland Revenue determines that the requirements were not met or an event has occurred since the effective date, they can issue a notice to the trustees and the vulnerable person stating that the election never had effect or ceased to have effect.
* Simplified point 3: A person aggrieved by a determination of the Board of Inland Revenue may appeal to the General Commissioners within 30 days of the notice of the determination.
* Simplified point 4: All necessary adjustments will be made to give effect to a determination under subsection (3), including discharge or repayment of tax, making of assessments, or otherwise.
* Simplified point 5: The chapter also includes definitions of key terms and modifications for application in relation to Scotland.

series.short: "Alternative Financing Definitions and Institutions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines alternative finance arrangements and financial institutions for the purpose of the chapter.
* Simplified point 2: Alternative finance arrangements include arrangements falling under sections 47 or 49, and financial institutions include banks, building societies, and certain authorized persons.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of financial institutions includes wholly-owned subsidiaries of banks and building societies, as well as persons authorized to carry on consumer credit or consumer hire businesses.
* Simplified point 4: The section also provides a definition of a wholly-owned subsidiary for the purposes of subsection (2)(c).

series.short: "Alternative Financing Arrangements for Financial Institutions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law states that when a financial institution buys an asset and then resells it to another party at a higher price, the difference between the two prices can be considered as a return on investment, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 2: The conditions for this arrangement include that the financial institution must purchase the asset for the purpose of entering into these types of arrangements, and at least one of the parties must be a financial institution.
* Simplified point 3: If the sale price is paid in installments, each installment includes alternative finance return equal to the appropriate amount, which is calculated as the interest that would be included in a loan made on arm's length terms.
* Simplified point 4: If the alternative finance return is paid in a currency other than sterling, it must be translated into sterling at a spot rate of exchange on the day the payment is made.
* Simplified point 5: Non-resident companies that receive alternative finance return are not considered to have a permanent establishment in the UK, provided that the arrangements are made for the purposes of a trade, profession, or vocation, or a property business.

series.short: "Financial Investment Arrangement: Earn Profits with Limited Liability"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section describes a type of financial arrangement where a person (the "depositor") deposits money with a financial institution, and the institution uses that money to generate profits. The institution then pays the depositor a portion of those profits, based on the amount they deposited.
* Simplified point 2: The payments made to the depositor are equivalent to the return on an investment of money at interest.
* Simplified point 3: The purpose of these arrangements is to provide a way for individuals to invest their money and earn a profit, similar to a savings account or an investment product.
* Simplified point 4: The financial institution is responsible for managing the funds and generating profits, while the depositor has limited liability and receives regular payments based on their investment.

series.short: "Alternative Finance Arrangements for Tax Purposes: Treatment and Exclusions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text describes how alternative finance arrangements should be treated for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: Alternative finance return or profit share return is treated as if it were interest for the purposes of ITTOIA 2005.
* Simplified point 3: Section 47 arrangements are excluded from the definition of "loan relationship" for the purposes of Chapter 2 of Part 4 of FA 1996.
* Simplified point 4: Profit share return is not treated as a distribution for the purposes of the Corporation Tax Acts.
* Simplified point 5: The text outlines provisions related to the treatment of alternative finance arrangements for tax purposes, including the exclusion of certain amounts from the definition of "loan relationship" and the treatment of profit share return as if it were interest.

series.short: "Tax Treatment of Alternative Financing Arrangements Under the Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This chapter of the Finance Act 2005 deals with how alternative financing arrangements will be treated for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The chapter applies to alternative financing arrangements entered into on or after April 6, 2005, but it also covers existing profit-sharing agreements that were in place before that date if payments are made on or after that date.
* Simplified point 3: For the purpose of income tax, this chapter only applies to payments made on or after April 6, 2005, under existing profit-sharing agreements to individuals other than companies.
* Simplified point 4: If a company is a party to existing profit-sharing agreements, this chapter applies to the company starting from April 6, 2005, and the loan treated by section 50 as made by or to the company is considered to be a loan made on April 6, 2005, of an amount equal to the notional carrying value of the asset or liability representing the existing profit-sharing arrangements.
* Simplified point 5: The notional carrying value is the amount that would have been the carrying value of the asset or liability in the company's accounts prepared according to generally accepted accounting practices if a financial period had ended just before April 6, 2005.
* Simplified point 6: Section 54 of the act applies to profit-share returns paid by a company on or after April 6, 2005, under existing profit-sharing agreements.

series.short: "UK Film Industry Tax Relief: Encouraging Production and Supporting the Arts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government has provided tax relief for limited-budget films to encourage film production and support the British film industry.
* Simplified point 2: The tax relief is available for expenditure incurred before 1st October 2007, but only if the film's principal photography began before 1st April 2006.
* Simplified point 3: The tax relief is also subject to certain conditions related to the completion of the film and its release.
* Simplified point 4: The Treasury can make orders to amend the enactments affected by the bill, including substituting later dates for those inserted by the bill.
* Simplified point 5: The changes made by the bill apply to claims made under Section 42 of the Finance Act 1992 on or after 2nd July 2005, and to deductions made under Sections 139 and 140 of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2005 on or after 2nd July 2005.

series.short: "Film Production Relief Restrictions Outlined in New Schedule"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract restricts the circumstances under which relief can be obtained for production and acquisition expenditure related to films.
* Simplified point 2: The restrictions are outlined in Part 1 of Schedule 3, which includes limitations on the types of expenses eligible for relief and the timing of the relief.
* Simplified point 3: Part 2 of Schedule 3 limits the amount of relief that can be obtained, based on factors such as the size of the production company and the amount of qualifying expenditure.
* Simplified point 4: Part 3 of Schedule 3 makes minor and consequential amendments to other laws related to film production.
* Simplified point 5: Part 4 of Schedule 3 contains interpretation provisions to ensure clarity and consistency in the application of the restrictions.

series.short: "Film Production Taxation Rules: Deferred Income Agreements and Allocation Periods"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 deals with the treatment of deferred income agreements related to film production. It outlines how the income from these agreements should be taxed over a 15-year period.
* Simplified point 2: The section applies when a company makes a claim for a deduction related to film expenses, and there are existing deferred income agreements in place. In this case, the company is treated as receiving income from the relevant trade equal to the amount of excess relief, which is calculated using a formula.
* Simplified point 3: The "excess relief" refers to the amount by which the deduction claimed exceeds the amount that would have been allowed if the deferred income agreements had not existed.
* Simplified point 4: The section also specifies how the income received through these deferred income agreements should be allocated to different periods for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 5: The "relevant film expenditure" refers to expenditure on the production or acquisition of the original master version of the film.

series.short: "Film Tax Law Definitions: Deferred Income Agreements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section defines what constitutes a "deferred income agreement in respect of a film" for the purpose of tax law.
* Simplified point 2: The definition includes two conditions - Condition A and Condition B - which must be met for an agreement to qualify as a deferred income agreement.
* Simplified point 3: Condition A requires the agreement to guarantee an amount of income arising from the exploitation of the film, and have a last date of deferral after the end of the 15-year period.
* Simplified point 4: Condition B supplements or varies an earlier agreement that guarantees income arising from the exploitation of the film, and has a last date of deferral after the end of the 15-year period.
* Simplified point 5: The section applies to all agreements, regardless of when they were made, and defines key terms such as "agreement" and "guarantee".

series.short: "Tax Treatment of Movie Income Deferrals"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law states that if a company claims a tax deduction for expenses related to a movie before entering into a deferred income agreement, then the company will be treated as receiving income from the movie in the period when the agreement is entered into.
* Simplified point 2: The amount of income treated as received is calculated using a formula based on the amount of excess relief claimed, the number of days in the 15-year period, and the number of days in the period between the operative date and the final deferral date.
* Simplified point 3: The "operative date" refers to the date the company acquired the original master version of the movie or, if the claim is only in respect of expenditure incurred on the acquisition of the original master version, the date of that acquisition.
* Simplified point 4: The "final deferral date" is the last date of deferral in relation to the deferred income agreement mentioned in subsection (1)(a).
* Simplified point 5: The law also defines "previous relevant agreement" as a deferred income agreement in respect of the movie that was entered into by the company after the claim was made and before the entry into the deferred income agreement mentioned in subsection (1)(a).
* Simplified point 6: The law specifies that the "relevant film expenditure" means expenditure of a revenue nature on the production or acquisition of the original master version of the movie.

series.short: "Film Completion and Tax Relief: Definitions and Requirements"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section defines when a film is considered complete for tax purposes.
* Simplified point 2: The section establishes that a company is not required to pay tax on agreements entered into before December 2, 2004, if the agreement was made to fulfill an existing unconditional obligation.
* Simplified point 3: The section provides definitions for "film," "original master version," and "relevant period" for the purposes of Sections 60-62.
* Simplified point 4: The section states that the Film Tax Relief is only available for films that are completed after December 2, 2004.

series.short: "Finance Act 2005 Transitional Provisions: Income Tax Definition and Corporate Tax Replacement"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The transitional provisions in Sections 60, 62, and 63 of the Finance Act 2005 apply to income tax purposes for the year 2004-05 and earlier years of assessment, making changes to the definition of "person" and replacing "corporation tax" with "income tax."
* Simplified point 2: These sections are deemed to have come into force on December 2, 2004.

series.short: "Film Production Taxation: Deferred Income Agreements & Calculating Taxable Profits"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the law outlines how deferred income agreements should be handled when calculating taxable profits for film productions.
* Simplified point 2: The section defines "deferred income agreements" and explains how they should be treated for tax purposes, including how excess relief can be brought into account and how the 15-year period is calculated.
* Simplified point 3: The section also covers how events A and B can affect the calculation of taxable profits, and how the "net excess relief" is determined.
* Simplified point 4: The law specifies that certain conditions must be met for an agreement to qualify as a "deferred income agreement," and that the agreement must guarantee an amount of income arising from the exploitation of the film.
* Simplified point 5: The section includes provisions related to the timing of entering into agreements and how unconditional obligations are treated.

series.short: "Tax Implications of Film Company Rights Sales: Legal Clause Explained"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The extract describes a legal clause regarding the tax implications of a film company's sale of rights to guaranteed income.
* Simplified point 2: The clause outlines the consequences of a "chargeable event" occurring, including the treatment of income received or losses brought forward, and the valuation of the "disposed rights."
* Simplified point 3: The section defines key terms such as "exit event," "exit accounting period," "chargeable amount," and "disposed rights."
* Simplified point 4: The clause explains how the guaranteed income agreement is valued, using the net present value of each payment.
* Simplified point 5: The section provides for the application of the temporal discount rate and specifies the rate to be used.

series.short: Removal of Restrictions on Interest Relief for Limited Partners
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Removes restrictions on interest relief for limited partners.
* Simplified point 2: Defines "contribution to the trade" for the purpose of determining relief for limited partners.
* Simplified point 3: Excludes certain amounts from being considered as part of an individual's contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 4: Provides for regulations to make different provision for different cases or purposes.
* Simplified point 5: Specifies the meaning of "relevant loss" for the purposes of the section.

series.short: "Recovery of Excess Relief: Understanding the Process and Implications"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law clause outlines the process for recovering excess relief given to individuals who make multiple claims for relief under Section 380 or 381 of the Income Tax Act 2005.
* Simplified point 2: The "chargeable event" occurs when there is a decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, resulting in the total losses claimed becoming greater than their contribution to the trade. At this point, the individual is treated as receiving income equal to the chargeable amount, which is subject to income tax.
* Simplified point 3: The "chargeable amount" is determined by taking the smallest of amounts A, B, and C, with amount A representing the amount of the relevant decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, amount B representing the amount given by subtracting any reclaimed relief from the total losses claimed, and amount C representing the amount by which the total losses claimed exceed the individual's contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 4: The law defines "relevant loss" as a loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a year of assessment the basis period for which begins on or after 2nd December 2004, or a post-announcement loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a straddling year of assessment.
* Simplified point 5: The transitional provision for years of assessment before the year 2005-06 states that the section applies in relation to years of assessment which are before the year 2005-06, and that subsection (4) of section 74 has effect as if for "individual - " to the end there were substituted "individual, the individual is to be treated as receiving at the time of the occurrence of the chargeable event annual profits or gains which are of an amount equal to the chargeable amount and are chargeable to income tax under Case VI of Schedule D."
* Simplified point 6: Consequential amendments include changes to sections 117(2) and 118ZF of ICTA, and section 121 of FA 2004, to reflect the new rules for recovering excess relief.

series.short: "Film Industry Regulatory Changes: Clarifying Capital Contributions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This legislative change allows the UK government to make regulations that exclude certain amounts when calculating an individual's capital contribution to a trade carried out in partnership, specifically in relation to film-related losses.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations can have retrospective effect, making provisions that take place before the regulations are made, and can also make supplementary, incidental, consequential, or transitional provisions as needed.
* Simplified point 3: The definition of "the individual's capital contribution to the trade" in Section 121 of the Finance Act 2004 is subject to regulations made under Section 122A, allowing for further clarification or modification of this definition.
* Simplified point 4: The amendments made by this section are deemed to have come into force on 2nd December 2004.

series.short: "New Accounting Practices for Loan Relationships and Derivative Contracts"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section changes the accounting practice for certain companies, allowing them to delay recording losses on loan relationships or derivative contracts until their first period of account beginning on or after January 1, 2006.
* Simplified point 2: The section also defines "securitization company" for the purposes of the Corporation Tax Acts and allows the Treasury to make regulations regarding the application of the Acts to such companies.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can provide for the amount of profits of a specified description to be taken to be a certain amount or calculated on a specific basis, and allow for adjustments to be made to the amount brought into account for corporation tax purposes.
* Simplified point 4: The section provides that the regulations may make different provisions for different descriptions of companies and that the first regulations under this section must be laid before and approved by a resolution of the House of Commons.

series.short: "Double Taxation Relief for Non-Resident Dividend Recipients in UK"
series.text:
* The simplified point 1 is: This clause allows for double taxation relief on dividends paid to non-UK residents, ensuring they don't pay tax twice on the same income.
* The simplified point 2: It applies specifically to dividends paid on or after March 16th, 2005, and only considers the tax laws of territories outside the United Kingdom.

series.short: "UK Foreign Tax Credit Rules: New Provisions & Impact on Income Tax & Corporation Tax"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The text describes various provisions related to foreign tax credits and their impact on income tax and corporation tax in the UK.
* Simplified point 2: The text introduces new sections 798A and 798B of the Income Tax (Earnings and Pensions) Act 2003, which provide rules for calculating foreign tax credits in certain situations. These sections cover cases such as hedging relationships with derivative contracts, transactions involving multiple jurisdictions, and aggregation of credits for foreign tax.
* Simplified point 3: The text also amends existing sections 796 and 797 of the Act to include references to the new sections 798A and 798B, and makes minor changes to the wording of these sections.
* Simplified point 4: The text specifies the dates from which the new provisions will apply, including payments of foreign tax made on or after 16th March 2005 for corporation tax, and payments of foreign tax made on or after 6th April 2005 for income tax.

series.short: "UK Government Cracks Down on Tax Avoidance Schemes Using Foreign Tax Credits"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government added a new section (804ZA) to the Income Tax Act (ICTA) to combat tax avoidance schemes that use foreign tax credits.
* Simplified point 2: This section allows HMRC to issue notices to individuals who have participated in these schemes, requiring them to make adjustments to their tax returns and potentially facing penalties.
* Simplified point 3: The notice will inform the individual of the Board's view that the scheme or arrangement is one that is designed to increase relief, and the amount of foreign tax that is considered to satisfy condition B of section 804ZA.
* Simplified point 4: If the individual receives a notice, they must make adjustments to their tax return for the period specified in the notice, and make any additional payments due.
* Simplified point 5: Failure to comply with the notice can result in penalties, and the individual may also be subject to an enquiry into their tax return.

series.short: "Tax Enquiry and Assessment Changes in the Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 makes changes to existing laws regarding tax enquiries and assessments.
* Simplified point 2: It adds new provisions to require taxpayers to be given notices under Section 804ZA of the Taxes Act 1988 for schemes and arrangements designed to increase tax relief.
* Simplified point 3: The amendments also restrict the powers of discovery assessments and remove the need for certain conditions to be met before an enquiry can be conducted.
* Simplified point 4: These changes aim to improve the ability of HMRC to detect and prevent tax avoidance schemes and arrangements.

series.short: "New Rules for Dividend Taxation and Foreign Taxation Relief for Controlled Foreign Companies"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The section of the law focuses on controlled foreign companies (CFCs) and their relationship with dividends and foreign taxation.
* Simplified point 2: The law introduces new rules for ADP (Advanced Pricing Agreement) controlled foreign companies (CFCs) regarding dividends and double taxation relief.
* Simplified point 3: The law amends existing sections of the Income Tax Act 2005 (ICTA) to exclude ADP CFCs from the definition of "company" for the purpose of section 803A, which deals with foreign taxation of groups as a single entity.
* Simplified point 4: The changes apply to dividends paid on or after December 2, 2004, and March 16, 2005, respectively.

series.short: "Tax Changes in the Finance Act 2005: Relief for Dividends and Annual Payments"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2005 makes changes to the tax treatment of annual payments and double taxation relief for dividends.
* Simplified point 2: The act removes the requirement to bring certain payments into account when calculating income tax or corporation tax.
* Simplified point 3: The act also makes changes to the way dividends are taxed between related companies, specifically removing a provision that previously limited the amount of tax relief available.
* Simplified point 4: The changes take effect on December 2, 2004, and apply to any annual payments made on or after that date, as well as to dividends paid on or after that date.

series.short: "Finance Act 2005 Renovation Incentives and Tonnage Tax Provisions"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 introduces capital allowances for renovations of business premises in disadvantaged areas, allowing companies to claim tax relief on eligible expenses.
* Simplified point 2: The schedule within the act outlines the specifics of how these capital allowances will be calculated and applied, including the types of expenses that are eligible and the deadline for incurring such expenses.
* Simplified point 3: Additionally, the act includes provisions related to tonnage tax, which is a tax system used to calculate taxes based on the weight of goods being transported.

series.short: "Stamp Duty Land Tax Changes in the Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2005 made changes to the amount of stamp duty land tax chargeable on certain transactions related to residential and non-residential properties.
* Simplified point 2: The act increased the threshold for stamp duty land tax on residential properties from £60,000 to £120,000, effective from March 16, 2005.
* Simplified point 3: The act also removed the disadvantaged areas relief for non-residential properties, effective from the same date.
* Simplified point 4: Additionally, the act made changes to the exemptions from stamp duty reserve tax for demutualization of insurance companies.

series.short: "Inheritance Tax Changes in the Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2005 makes changes to inheritance tax rates and limits for the next three years starting from 2005-06.
* Simplified point 2: The act introduces new tables for inheritance tax rates and limits for each year from 2005-06 to 2007-08, with different lower and upper limits for each year.
* Simplified point 3: The act also makes changes to the way inheritance tax rates are indexed to reflect changes in inflation, specifically excluding certain differences in the retail price index from 2003 to 2006.
* Simplified point 4: Additionally, the act amends the Landfill Tax rate and allows government departments to incur expenses related to preparing for the Lorry Road User Charge.

series.short: "Tax Regulations for Pension Schemes: Finance Act 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2005 allows the government to create regulations regarding taxes for pension schemes and related matters.
* Simplified point 2: These regulations can impose various taxes such as income tax, capital gains tax, corporation tax, inheritance tax, value-added tax, and stamp duty land tax.
* Simplified point 3: The regulations can also provide exemptions and reliefs from these taxes, including exemption from charges on certain income and gains arising from assets of the Pension Protection Fund and the Fraud Compensation Fund.
* Simplified point 4: The regulations can apply to times both before and after April 6th, 2006, and can include consequential, supplementary, and transitional provisions.
* Simplified point 5: The regulations will be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of the House of Commons.

series.short: "Equality in Taxation: Government Empowered to Remove Inequality Based on Gender or Marital Status"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This clause allows the government to make regulations to treat civil partnerships and marriages equally when it comes to taxes and duties.
* Simplified point 2: The regulations can provide for variations in how events are treated based on gender or marital status, and can also amend existing laws to ensure equality of treatment.
* Simplified point 3: The clause gives the government the power to make regulations to remove any inequality of treatment based on gender or marital status.
* Simplified point 4: The power to make regulations includes the ability to make different provisions for different cases, and to make incidental, supplemental, consequential, or transitional provisions.
* Simplified point 5: The clause applies to all enactments passed or made at any time before the end of the session following the one in which the Finance Act was passed.

series.short: "Repeal of Outdated Tax Laws (Finance Act 2005)"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This section of the Finance Act 2005 repeals several old laws related to taxation that are no longer useful or relevant.
* Simplified point 2: The repealed laws include provisions for alcoholic liquor duties, capital allowances, hydrocarbon oil duties, income and corporation taxes, inheritance tax, and vehicle excise duty.
* Simplified point 3: The repeals take effect subject to certain commencement provisions and savings as specified in Schedule 11 of the Act.
* Simplified point 4: The Act defines various terms used in the legislation, including "ALDA 1979", "CAA 2001", "FA", "F(No.2)A", "HODA 1979", "ICTA", "IHTA 1984", "ITEPA 2003", "ITTOIA 2005", "TCGA 1992", and "TMA 1970".

series.short: "UK Budget Update: Tax Rates & Exemptions for 2005"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Finance Act 2005 sets out the rates of duty for different types of tobacco products in the UK, specifically cigarettes, cigars, hand-rolling tobacco, and other smoking tobacco and chewing tobacco.
* Simplified point 2: The rates of duty on beer have been increased from £12.59 to £12.92.
* Simplified point 3: The updated rates of hydrocarbon oil duties in the UK, effective from September 1st, 2005, include adjustments to the prices of various fuels, such as ultra-low sulfur petrol, sulphur-free petrol, light oil, and heavy oil.
* Simplified point 4: Changes to the Vehicle Excise Duty (VED) rates for certain types of vehicles, including light passenger vehicles based on their CO2 emissions figures, and updates to the trailer supplement rates, will be applied to licenses taken out on or after March 17th, 2005.
* Simplified point 5: The special trust rate will be charged at 19% for the financial year 2005, and will only apply to the first slice of trust income.
* Simplified point 6: Childcare vouchers, workplace parking, cycles, and armed forces pensions are among the items exempt from tax.
* Simplified point 7: Employees who acquire shares in a spin-out company from a research institution may be eligible for tax relief, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 8: Research institution spin-out companies may elect to treat certain shares or interests in shares as employment income, subject to certain conditions.
* Simplified point 9: The Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rules regarding the calculation of the gain on the disposal of certain types of shares have been modified.
* Simplified point 10: Vulnerable individuals who receive income from qualifying trusts can claim special tax treatment, reducing their liability to income tax.

series.short: Recovery of Excess Relief Under Income Tax Act 2005: A Guide to Simplified Points
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: This law clause outlines the process for recovering excess relief given to individuals who make multiple claims for relief under Section 380 or 381 of the Income Tax Act 2005.
* Simplified point 2: The "chargeable event" occurs when there is a decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, resulting in the total losses claimed becoming greater than their contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 3: The "chargeable amount" is determined by taking the smallest of amounts A, B, and C, with amount A representing the amount of the relevant decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, amount B representing the amount given by subtracting any reclaimed relief from the total losses claimed, and amount C representing the amount by which the total losses claimed exceed the individual's contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 4: The law defines "relevant loss" as a loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a year of assessment the basis period for which begins on or after 2nd December 2004, or a post-announcement loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a straddling year of assessment.
* Simplified point 5: The transitional provision for years of assessment before the year 2005-06 states that the section applies in relation to years of assessment which are before the year 2005-06, and that subsection (4) of section 74 has effect as if for "individual - " to the end there were substituted "individual, the individual is to be treated as receiving at the time of the occurrence of the chargeable event annual profits or gains which are of an amount equal to the chargeable amount and are chargeable to income tax under Case VI of Schedule D."
* Simplified point 6: Consequential amendments include changes to sections 117(2) and 118ZF of ICTA, and section 121 of FA 2004, to reflect the new rules for recovering excess relief.

series.short: Recovery of Excess Relief Under Income Tax Act 2005: A Guide to the Process and Key Definitions
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: Recovery of excess relief under Income Tax Act 2005 involves a process where individuals who make multiple claims for relief under Sections 380 or 381 of the Act can recover excess relief given to them.
* Simplified point 2: The process involves determining the "chargeable event," which occurs when there is a decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, resulting in the total losses claimed becoming greater than their contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 3: The "chargeable amount" is determined by taking the smallest of amounts A, B, and C, with amount A representing the amount of the relevant decrease in the individual's contribution to the trade, amount B representing the amount given by subtracting any reclaimed relief from the total losses claimed, and amount C representing the amount by which the total losses claimed exceed the individual's contribution to the trade.
* Simplified point 4: The law defines "relevant loss" as a loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a year of assessment the basis period for which begins on or after 2nd December 2004, or a post-announcement loss sustained by the individual in the relevant trade in a straddling year of assessment.
* Simplified point 5: Transitional provisions apply to years of assessment before the year 2005-06, with subsection (4) of section 74 having effect as if for "individual - " to the end there were substituted "individual, the individual is to be treated as receiving at the time of the occurrence of the chargeable event annual profits or gains which are of an amount equal to the chargeable amount and are chargeable to income tax under Case VI of Schedule D."
* Simplified point 6: Consequential amendments include changes to sections 117(2) and 118ZF of ICTA, and section 121 of FA 2004, to reflect the new rules for recovering excess relief.

summary:
The Finance Act 2005 contains provisions related to tax rates, exemptions, and recovery of excess relief for individuals involved in trades or businesses. Key simplified points include:
1. Rates of duty for tobacco products, beer, and hydrocarbon oil duties have been updated.
2. Changes to vehicle excise duty (VED) rates for certain types of vehicles, including light passenger vehicles based on their CO2 emissions figures, and updates to trailer supplement rates.
3. Special trust rate charged at 19% for the financial year 2005, applicable to the first slice of trust income.
4. Childcare vouchers, workplace parking, cycles, and armed forces pensions are among the items exempt from tax.
5. Employees acquiring shares in a spin-out company from a research institution may be eligible for tax relief, subject to certain conditions.
6. Research institution spin-out companies may elect to treat certain shares or interests in shares as employment income, subject to certain conditions.
7. Modifications to the Capital Gains Tax (CGT) rules regarding the calculation of the gain on the disposal of certain types of shares.
8. Persons aggrieved by a determination of the Board of Inland Revenue may appeal to the General Commissioners within 30 days of the notice of the determination.
9. Definitions of key terms and modifications for application in relation to Scotland.
10. Wholly-owned subsidiaries of banks and building societies are considered as financial institutions for the purpose of the chapter.
This summary highlights the main points of the Finance Act 2005, focusing on the impacts of the legislation on individuals and businesses. It simplifies complex legal language to ensure clarity and ease of understanding for all readers.
